doc.field: 43. Prayer Before Singing Mountain Spirit Songs, Chiricahua Apache Text

The Apache language texts have been converted from Hoijer's original orthography to a contemporary practical orthography currently in use for Navajo and several other Apachean languages. See de Reuse, Willem (Ethnological Note An Introduction to Western Apache Linguistics (3 vols). unpublished manuscript Tucson: University of Arizona. Adapted from the orthography employed in Robert Young and William Morgan's (Ethnological Note Navajo Language: a Grammar and Colloquial Dictionary. Albuquerque: University of New Mexico Press.

Authorship attributions. The Chiricahua singer/ceremonial specialist is designated author/performer of particular song texts. Hoijer is designated author of the collection as a whole, and is sole author of the linguistic analysis portions.
This prayer is the English translation of one of the Ethnological Note bilingual Apache language texts when appear in this collection.

apache, apachean, southern athabaskan, southern athapaskan, chiricahua apache, mescalero apache,
apache language, southern athapaskan language, southern athabaskan language
Apache song, Apache ceremony, Native American songs, Apache prayer, Native American prayer

Chiricahua Apache Text 43. Prayer Before Singing Mountain Spirit Songs as told by David Fatty The Big Blue Mountain Spirits, (43.1) Gáͅhéntsodatł'izhń, Gáͅhéntsołitsoń, Gáͅhéntsołigań, Gáͅhéntsodiłhiłń: Ha'óó'áͅ 'ázhiͅ kooghaͅ, Nandi'á 'ázhiͅ kooghaͅ, 'I'óó'áͅ 'ázhiͅ kooghaͅ, Náhákosí 'ázhiͅ kooghaͅ. The Big Blue Mountain Spirits, The Big Yellow Mountain Spirits, The Big White Mountain Spirits, The Big Black Mountain Spirits: Their homes are in the east, Their homes are in the south, Their homes are in the west, Their homes are in the north. Linguistic Notes by Harry Hoijer
43. Prayer Before Singing Mountain Spirit Songs, Chiricahua Apache Text
